department: Agency of Commerce and Community Development
bid_description: Through this Request for Proposal (RFP) the Agency of Commerce and Community Development, Department of Tourism and Marketing (hereinafter the “State”) seeks the professional services of a qualified firm to develop a Destination Management Strategic Plan for the state of Vermont to help guide and support the sustainability and economic success of Vermont’s tourism industry. The Plan should outline the current state of tourism in Vermont and provide strategic guidance and priorities around which the State and Vermont’s tourism industry can unite to align economic growth with a recognized need to balance residential quality of life and maintain the inherent qualities that make Vermont such a treasured destination.

bid_title: Manufactured Home Communities Flood Resiliency Planning
bid_description: In 2023, an assessment of the flood risk at Manufactured Home Communities (MHC) in Vermont was completed mere weeks before severe floods impacted some of these communities. Consequently, this is an important time to record the experiences of those impacted, take stock of lessons learned and to continue to acquire information from the affected communities and individuals regarding the impact of the flooding. Little information has been available about the decisions and outcomes of people affected by the flooding. Establishing and maintaining long term relationships with those individuals and communities significantly impacted by flooding may allow DEC to improve the State’s work beyond the extent of this funding. Most importantly, the State needs to keep working through the established relationships with MHC as part of the learning process in terms of evaluating environmental justice factors regarding flood safety and identifying the co-benefits of floodplain function including clean water, health, and social connection.

bid_title: Vermont Landslide Susceptibility Modeling
department: Agency of Natural Resources, Dept. of Environmental Conserv.
bid_description: The Vermont Geological Survey (VGS) has been engaged in assessing and inventorying landslide hazards in the state for many years; however, the magnitude of our vulnerability was not made fully clear until the July 2023 storm. After dozens of landslides were initiated by heavy precipitation and soil saturation, the VGS and its partners received requests to visit over 80 locations to assess hazards associated with slope instability. One year later, after another intense storm, the VGS responded to nearly 150 such requests. The VGS has received multiple inquiries into Vermont’s susceptibility to future high-magnitude landslide-triggering events, and specifically for maps of susceptibility. The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) will begin requiring such information in future State Hazard Mitigation Plan (SHMP) drafts. A statewide landslide susceptibility map may be useful to Regional Planning Commissions, the Vermont Department of Public Safety, local fire departments and first responders, and the general public. DEC is seeking proposals for creating a landslide susceptibility map for the entire state of Vermont for integration into the 2028 SHMP. Up to $116,964 is available for May 1, 2025 through June 1, 2026.

bid_title: Low Emission Vehicle Program and Automotive Technician Training
department: Agency of Natural Resources, Dept. of Environmental Conserv.
bid_description: The Vermont Low Emission Vehicle (LEV) Program is part of Vermont's overall strategy to control air pollution from motor vehicles. The Vermont LEV Program is also part of broader regional efforts to reduce air pollution from motor vehicles. Several other northeast states have implemented LEV programs. Combined, these LEV programs bring a significant number of vehicles that emit less air pollution to the northeast. All Vermonters benefit from improved air quality and Vermont motorists realize significant consumer benefits such as longer vehicle useful life requirements, stronger recall provisions, and greater warranty coverage. Inspection and maintenance (IM) of vehicle air pollution control systems is an important and cost-effective air pollution abatement strategy. Inspection requirements for these systems have been successfully integrated into the Vermont Vehicle Inspection Program. Since January 1, 2001, vehicles failing emissions inspections must be repaired prior to receiving a valid inspection sticker. While the Vehicle Inspection Program can identify vehicles with malfunctioning air pollution control systems, it is only through accurate diagnosis and proper repairs that the excess air pollution from these vehicles will be cost effectively reduced. Providing information and training to Vermont automotive technicians on accurately diagnosing and effectively repairing motor vehicles that have failed the inspection is essential to this effort. DEC is seeking proposals for a grant to conduct evaluation of, and outreach for Vermont’s LEV Program, and to develop, offer and deliver training classes to automotive repair technicians throughout the State. Up to $275,250.00 is available for the initial award, though it is anticipated more may become available for this project during the period of performance to be added via an agreement amendment or renewal process contingent on satisfactory performance.

bid_title: Flood and Climate Resilience Mitigation Materials
department: Agency of Natural Resources, Dept. of Environmental Conserv.
bid_description: The State is requesting proposals to develop outreach materials to support the understanding of Vermonters regarding flood hazards, mitigation alternatives, and the benefits of naturally functioning floodplains and river systems.

bid_title: 2024 ARPA Healthy Homes- Manufactured Housing Communities Water Infrastructure Improvements
department: Agency of Natural Resources, Dept. of Environmental Conserv.
bid_description: This program seeks to provide adequate drinking water, wastewater, stormwater, and drainage systems to manufactured housing communities (MHCs). MHCs are an important source of affordable housing in Vermont and the majority of residents are of low to moderate income households. As housing prices and shortages have increased throughout the pandemic, the need for safe and affordable housing in the state has become even more apparent. However, MHCs historically have been disproportionally impacted by emergency events and infrastructure issues. Today, several MHCs face severe water infrastructure deficiencies that make it difficult or impossible to shelter in place safely during the pandemic or other unforeseen state of emergency. This program will confront this challenge by providing grants for eligible MHCs to repair, replace, or build wastewater, drinking water, stormwater, or drainage systems.

bid_title: Waterbury Dam Tunnel and Penstock Inspection Project: Construction Manager
department: Agency of Natural Resources, Dept. of Environmental Conserv.
bid_description: The Vermont Department of Environmental Conservation (DEC), Dam Safety Program (DSP) is seeking to assemble an integrated team to perform inspection and assessment of the tunnel and penstocks and perform maintenance to downstream gates at the Waterbury Dam in Waterbury, Vermont, on a critical path schedule. The DSP is seeking technical and fee proposals from qualified Construction Managers experienced with critical path delivery, dam safety projects, dam tunnel, penstocks, and gates, management of subcontractors including divers and gate mechanics, and confined space entry safety protocols and requirements. Familiarity with the Waterbury Dam, the outlet works configuration and operation, flood control, Green Mountain Power’s operations, and competing reservoir uses is preferred.

bid_title: 2024 LANDSLIDE SUCEPTIBILITY MAPPING & MODELING
department: Agency of Natural Resources, Dept. of Environmental Conserv.
bid_description: The Vermont Geological Survey (VGS), a Division within the Department of Environmental Conservation (DEC) has been involved with landslide assessment and mapping for many years. Along with our partners, the State of Vermont (hereinafter the “State”) has performed landslide inventories for five of 14 counties in Vermont and created a “Report a Landslide” web tool that allows citizens to report landslide observations. The State’s landslide database has grown to include over 3000 documented landslides and unstable gullies. Even as the State’s inventory grew, the magnitude of vulnerability was not made fully clear until the aftermath of the July 2023 storm, when dozens of landslides were initiated by heavy precipitation and soil saturation. The State and our partners received requests to visit over 80 locations to assess hazards associated with slope instability. Since the July 2023 storm, the State has received multiple inquiries into Vermont’s susceptibility to future high-magnitude landslide-triggering events, and specifically for maps of susceptibility. The State is beginning to fill the need for these maps for the eastern portion of Vermont: this Request for Proposals is to provide susceptibility mapping coverage for the Vermont Piedmont and Northeast Highlands provinces (the Area of Interest, or “AOI”). This project aims to establish a multivariate analysis method in a geographical information system (GIS) that is capable of identifying landslide-prone areas. Topographic datasets including slope steepness and stream. Proximity will be derived from the best available Light Detection and Ranging (LiDAR) topographic data and used along with other terrain elements including bedrock outcrops, landcover, soil erodibility, and hydrologic groups. Each of these parameters will be incorporated into a multivariate analysis using a weighted overlay function in ArcMap GIS to create composite risk assessment maps. The State is seeking proposals for this work with up to $16,375.00 available for compensation in the period April 15, 2024, to September 15, 2024. The sub-awardee must document third-party match of $16,375.00.

bid_title: Evaluation of Sludge Management in Vermont
department: Agency of Natural Resources, Dept. of Environmental Conserv.
bid_description: The State of Vermont Department of Environmental Conservation is seeking a consultant to perform a comprehensive evaluation of sludge management in Vermont and to make recommendations for strategies to best manage this material under various scenarios.

bid_title: Pike Hill Copper Mine Superfund Site Archeological Data Recovery
department: Agency of Natural Resources, Dept. of Environmental Conserv.
bid_description: The State of Vermont is seeking proposals for archeological data recovery to be completed at the Pike Hill Copper Mine Superfund Site located in Corinth, Vermont, beginning in 2024 prior to ground disturbing components of the Non-Time Critical Removal Action at the site.

bid_title: 2024 Lake Wise Property Assessments
department: Agency of Natural Resources, Dept. of Environmental Conserv.
bid_description: DEC is seeking proposals from vendors to conduct Lake Wise property assessments at various Vermont lakes. The Lake Wise program focuses on already existing shoreland development, and is a voluntary, non-regulatory assessment and education program for private landowners, businesses, and towns to learn how to manage their lake shore property to reduce erosion, sedimentation, and nutrient pollution through reducing stormwater flow over their property, increasing habitat, and supporting biodiversity in the process. The Lake Wise program awards properties that meet the criteria of the assessment a Lake Wise Award, which is a physical metal sign displayed on the property to show others on the lake that the property is being managed in an ecological and lake friendly manner.

bid_title: 2024 Hazardous Waste Spill Cleanup
department: Agency of Natural Resources, Dept. of Environmental Conserv.
bid_description: The State is seeking proposals for the performance of spill cleanup and hazardous waste disposal services in cases where the State is acting as the lead agency. Up to $1,000,000 is available for up to 5 years. Since this Request for Proposals (RFP) does not contain spill-specific information which may affect the cost of service, proposals will be accepted on a time and materials basis. However, the actual final cost of services will be negotiated in the final contract with the State. Please include with your proposal your markup for subcontractors and equipment (markup is not to exceed 10% or $1,000). Note: markups for regular site costs (such as utilities) and primary contractor services (such as telephone calls, copying, mailing costs, meals, digital scanning, lodging) will not be allowed under this contract. The State anticipates signing multiple contracts under the terms of this RFP. This will allow the State to select the most appropriate contractor(s) for a specific job based upon cost, location, availability, and services provided under the terms of the contract. Contract holders will draw upon a general contract limit of $1,000,000, subject to available funding. Contract duration will be from July 1, 2024, to June 30, 2026. The State may extend the contract for up to three (3) additional one-year periods with rate negotiations possible at the time of contract extension at the start of year 3, year 4, and year 5. The State will contact a contractor when the State spill contract cleanup work is required at a spill/incident. Based upon previous experience, the State anticipates that each contractor shall perform from 10 to 50 spill cleanups during the contract period. However, it is possible that a selected contractor will not conduct any spill cleanups during the contract period (although this is very unlikely).

Based upon previous experience, the State anticipates that each contractor shall perform from 10 to 50 spill cleanups during the contract period. However, it is possible that a selected contractor will not conduct any spill cleanups during the contract period (although this is very unlikely).

bid_title: Little Hosmer Dam Comprehensive Assessment
department: Agency of Natural Resources, Dept. of Environmental Conserv.
bid_description: The objective of this project is to perform assessment and to develop alternatives for the dam to address existing deficiencies and bring it into compliance with current dam safety rules and requirements. The project will provide conceptual level alternatives, design requirements, data gaps, permitting requirements, opinions of probable cost, and other pros / cons to be considered by project stakeholders in the selection of a preferred alternative to carry forward to final design and construction, which will be contracted under a separate project.

bid_title: Waterbury Dam Tunnel and Penstock Inspection Project: Consulting Dam Safety Engineer
department: Agency of Natural Resources, Dept. of Environmental Conserv.
bid_description: The Vermont Department of Environmental Conservation (DEC), Dam Safety Program (DSP) is seeking to assemble an integrated team to perform inspection and assessment of the tunnel and penstocks and perform maintenance to downstream gates at the Waterbury Dam in Waterbury, Vermont, on a critical path schedule. The DSP is seeking technical and fee proposals from qualified dam safety engineering consultants experienced with dam inspection, structural inspection investigation and assessment, steel penstock and concrete tunnel investigation and analysis, dam safety project planning, structural design, field monitoring of dive inspections, tunnel cleaning, gate repair, and general dam safety consultant services. Familiarity with the Waterbury Dam, the outlet works configuration and operation, flood control, Green Mountain Power’s operations, and competing reservoir uses is preferred.

bid_title: Pike Hill Copper Mine Superfund Site Archeological Data Recovery
department: Agency of Natural Resources, Dept. of Environmental Conserv.
bid_description: The State of Vermont is seeking proposals for archeological data recovery to be completed at the Pike Hill Copper Mine Superfund Site located in Corinth, Vermont, beginning in 2024 prior to ground disturbing components of the Non-Time Critical Removal Action at the site.

bid_title: 2024 Hazardous Waste Spill Cleanup
department: Agency of Natural Resources, Dept. of Environmental Conserv.
bid_description: The State is seeking proposals for the performance of spill cleanup and hazardous waste disposal services in cases where the State is acting as the lead agency. Up to $1,000,000 is available for up to 5 years. Since this Request for Proposals (RFP) does not contain spill-specific information which may affect the cost of service, proposals will be accepted on a time and materials basis. However, the actual final cost of services will be negotiated in the final contract with the State. Please include with your proposal your markup for subcontractors and equipment (markup is not to exceed 10% or $1,000). Note: markups for regular site costs (such as utilities) and primary contractor services (such as telephone calls, copying, mailing costs, meals, digital scanning, lodging) will not be allowed under this contract. The State anticipates signing multiple contracts under the terms of this RFP. This will allow the State to select the most appropriate contractor(s) for a specific job based upon cost, location, availability, and services provided under the terms of the contract. Contract holders will draw upon a general contract limit of $1,000,000, subject to available funding. Contract duration will be from July 1, 2024, to June 30, 2026. The State may extend the contract for up to three (3) additional one-year periods with rate negotiations possible at the time of contract extension at the start of year 3, year 4, and year 5. The State will contact a contractor when the State spill contract cleanup work is required at a spill/incident. Based upon previous experience, the State anticipates that each contractor shall perform from 10 to 50 spill cleanups during the contract period. However, it is possible that a selected contractor will not conduct any spill cleanups during the contract period (although this is very unlikely).

bid_title: 2024 Lake Wise Property Assessments
department: Agency of Natural Resources, Dept. of Environmental Conserv.
bid_description: DEC is seeking proposals from vendors to conduct Lake Wise property assessments at various Vermont lakes. The Lake Wise program focuses on already existing shoreland development, and is a voluntary, non-regulatory assessment and education program for private landowners, businesses, and towns to learn how to manage their lake shore property to reduce erosion, sedimentation, and nutrient pollution through reducing stormwater flow over their property, increasing habitat, and supporting biodiversity in the process. The Lake Wise program awards properties that meet the criteria of the assessment a Lake Wise Award, which is a physical metal sign displayed on the property to show others on the lake that the property is being managed in an ecological and lake friendly manner.

bid_title: Compost Technical Assistance and Operator Training 2024
department: Agency of Natural Resources, Dept. of Environmental Conserv.
bid_description: Vermont’s Universal Recycling Law (Act 148) seeks to reduce waste and improve statewide diversion rates for recyclable and compostable materials (organics). Diverted food scraps in Vermont are often composted. To support both new and existing food scrap composters with composting, the State’s Waste Management and Prevention Division, Solid Waste Management Program seeks proposals for a two-year contract with a renewal option for three additional years.

bid_title: 2024 Aquatic Nuisance Control - Environmental Stewardship Program
department: Agency of Natural Resources, Dept. of Environmental Conserv.
bid_description: The Vermont Department of Environmental Conservation (VTDEC) Lakes and Ponds Management and Protection Program (LPMPP) works to protect, maintain, enhance, and restore Vermont lakes and the public uses that healthy lake ecosystems provide through outreach and education, monitoring and assessment, and regulatory programs. The Aquatic Invasive Species Program is within the LPMPP and administers the Aquatic Nuisance Control Grant-in-Aid (GIA) Environmental Stewardship Program. This stewardship program provides financial assistance through a Participating Costs Agreement to municipalities and agencies of the State for aquatic nuisance species environmental stewardship projects. Funding for this program comes from the State General Fund, a portion of annual revenues from motorboat registration fees, and may also be supplemented by federal funds provided by the Army Corps of Engineers. Available funding in 2024 is estimated at $850,000.00.

This stewardship program provides financial assistance through a Participating Costs Agreement to municipalities and agencies of the State for aquatic nuisance species environmental stewardship projects. Funding for this program comes from the State General Fund, a portion of annual revenues from motorboat registration fees, and may also be supplemented by federal funds provided by the Army Corps of Engineers. Available funding in 2024 is estimated at $850,000.00.

bid_title: Maintenance of Seepage Control Systems, Waterbury Dam, Waterbury, Vermont
department: Agency of Natural Resources, Dept. of Environmental Conserv.
bid_description: The State of Vermont is seeking proposals for maintenance work including the documenting, testing, and cleaning of dewatering wells, and the cleaning and camera inspection of conduit filter drain outlet pipes located at the Waterbury Dam in Waterbury, Vermont.

bid_title: 2024 Labroatory Analytics Services
department: Agency of Natural Resources, Dept. of Environmental Conserv.
bid_description: The State is seeking proposals for Laboratory Analytical Services 2024. Up to $200,000 is available for 2 years.

bid_title: 2025 Aquatic Nuisance Control - Grant-In-Aid Program
department: Agency of Natural Resources, Dept. of Environmental Conserv.
bid_description: The Vermont Department of Environmental Conservation (VTDEC) Lakes and Ponds Management and Protection Program (LPMPP) works to protect, maintain, enhance, and restore Vermont lakes and the public uses that healthy lake ecosystems provide. The Aquatic Invasive Species Program within the LPMPP coordinates management activities associated with both aquatic invasive and nuisance species; works with local, state, and federal partners to obtain and provide funds for control projects; and provides education and outreach to reduce the threat and spread of aquatic invasive species. An “aquatic nuisance” is an undesirable or excessive substance or population that interferes with the recreational potential or aquatic habitat of a waterbody, and includes plants, animals, and algal populations. 10 V.S.A. § 1458 allows a municipality or agency of the State to apply to the Agency of Natural Resources for funding to assist with control of aquatic nuisances. The Aquatic Invasive Species Program administers the Aquatic Nuisance Control (ANC) Grant-in-Aid (GIA) Program to provide financial assistance for eligible projects. Aquatic nuisance species environmental stewardship projects fall into three categories: Greeter Projects, Management Projects, and Education, Outreach, or Survey Projects.

bid_description: The Vermont Department of Environmental Conservation (VTDEC) Lakes and Ponds Management and Protection Program (LPMPP) works to protect, maintain, enhance, and restore Vermont lakes and the public uses that healthy lake ecosystems provide. The Aquatic Invasive Species Program within the LPMPP coordinates management activities associated with both aquatic invasive and nuisance species; works with local, state, and federal partners to obtain and provide funds for control projects; and provides education and outreach to reduce the threat and spread of aquatic invasive species. An “aquatic nuisance” is an undesirable or excessive substance or population that interferes with the recreational potential or aquatic habitat of a waterbody, and includes plants, animals, and algal populations. 10 V.S.A. § 1458 allows a municipality or agency of the State to apply to the Agency of Natural Resources for funding to assist with control of aquatic nuisances. The Aquatic Invasive Species Program administers the Aquatic Nuisance Control (ANC) Grant-in-Aid (GIA) Program to provide financial assistance for eligible projects. Aquatic nuisance species environmental stewardship projects fall into three categories: Greeter Projects, Management Projects, and Education, Outreach, or Survey Projects.

department: Agency of Natural Resources, Dept. of Environmental Conserv.

bid_title: Maintenance at State-Owned Dams
department: Agency of Natural Resources, Dept. of Environmental Conserv.

bid_title: Automotive Emissions Repair Assistance Pilot Program

bid_title: 2024 Volkswagen Environmental Mitigation Trust: Eligible Mitigation Actions
department: Agency of Natural Resources, Dept. of Environmental Conserv.
bid_description: Since 2018, DEC has been developing project funding opportunities to implement projects that achieve significant reductions in diesel emissions from diesel powered engines, vehicles and equipment operating in Vermont. The purpose of this Request-for-Applications is to award funding to eligible projects that reduce NOx emissions from mobile sources in the most cost-effective way possible and demonstrate the feasibility of all-electric heavy-duty vehicles. DEC is seeking applications for eligible mitigation actions under the Volkswagen EMT pertaining to the all-electric replacement or repower of Class 4-8 local freight trucks and Class 4-8 school, shuttle, or transit buses. Of the total $5,796,400 available in funding under this Request-for-Applications, half will be allocated projects involving Class 4-8 local freight trucks and half will be allocated to projects involving Class 4-8 school, shuttle, or transit buses. DEC reserves the right to modify these allocation percentages based on applicant interest. The project period for this funding begins on January 1, 2025 and ends on December 31, 2026. Time extensions may be considered on a case-by-case basis.

bid_title: SHSO TRCC Annual Planning Services 2025
bid_description: The Vermont State Highway Safety Office (SHSO) of the Vermont Agency of Transportation, hereinafter referred to as VTrans, is seeking contractor services to perform consulting services at the request of the Traffic Records Coordinating Committee (TRCC). This will include coordinating and attending regular TRCC meetings, providing the TRCC meeting agenda, and posting to the SharePoint site and provide support for quarterly reports to NHTSA. The contractor will coordinate sharing and integrations of safety data between data systems, assist in the monitoring of the TRCC approved statewide data improvement programs compliance, and with the TRCC chair to prioritize TRCC projects using an expert understanding of Vermont Traffic Records.

bid_title: Go! Vermont Vanpool Program 2025
bid_description: The scope of work described herein is provided to outline the services desired by the Vermont Agency of Transportation (VTrans) for operating commuter vanpools, and should not be considered either comprehensive or restrictive to innovation or creativity on the part of the Contractor(s) in the preparation of the work plan. VTrans has no estimate of the quantities of services to be purchased under this agreement, and no guarantee to purchase an exact amount of service is intended or implied. There are currently six (6) vehicles in operation within the Vanpool Program. It is a priority for the Go!Vermont Program to increase the number of vanpools in operation and will potentially contract for services with more than one company.

bid_title: State Highway Safety Office Annual Distracted Driving Survey 2025
bid_description: The Office of Highway Safety of the Vermont Agency of Transportation, hereinafter referred to as VTrans, is seeking vendors to oversee a distracted driving observational survey to evaluate handheld device, blue tooth or manipulation of a device on Vermont roadways. This survey will be performed in an agreed timeframe that should remain consistent from year-to-year. The vendor will also compile and analyze the survey data to calculate data. Finally, the vendor will provide comprehensive narrative reports summarizing all activities undertaken for the observation surveys, identifying any differences among regions, vehicle types, gender, days of the week, types of distraction, time of day and drivers.

bid_title: On-Call Hydraulic Engineering Services 2025
bid_description: The Vermont Agency of Transportation, hereinafter referred to as VTrans, is seeking Contractor services to assist in the hydraulic evaluation of transportation projects on an on-call basis. The selected Contractor, hereinafter referred to as the CONTRACTOR, shall be responsible for performing hydraulic evaluations that will include emergency river response inspections and recommendations, hydraulic model development, hydrological modeling/calculations, and hydraulic recommendations for a variety of bridge, roadway and related transportation facilities.

bid_title: State Highway Safety Office Annual Seatbelt Survey 2025
bid_description: The vendor will oversee a safety belt observational survey to evaluate safety belt use in Vermont after the annual May Buckle Up/”Click It or Ticket” enforcement mobilizations in 2025 and 2026. The vendor will also compile and analyze the survey data to calculate the three values needed to complete the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) State Seat Belt Use Survey Reporting Form (weighted usage rate, standard error rate, and non-response rate) for each year of observation. Finally, the vendor will provide comprehensive narrative reports summarizing all activities undertaken for the observation surveys, identifying any differences among regions, vehicle types, gender, and/or passengers/drivers. The vendor will begin observational seatbelt data collection within five (5) working days immediately following the conclusion of the Spring Buckle Up/”Click It or Ticket” National Mobilization. All data must be gathered for compiling within twenty-one (21) days. Any deviation from the preapproved schedule must be approved in advance by the SHSO Highway Safety Program Coordinator.

bid_title: Railroad Engineering & Design Services 2025
bid_description: The Agency of Transportation, hereinafter referred to as VTrans, is seeking consultant services to assist in the development of railroad bridge, culvert, slope, railroad/highway crossing, Amtrak stations & platforms, railroad track projects, and emergency inspection and design. The selected consultants, hereinafter referred to as the Contractor, shall be responsible for performing a variety of project management, design, engineering, bridge inspection, construction services, load rating, environmental permitting, right-of-way services, and bidding services ranging from project definition through contract plan submittal and construction engineering/administration services during construction. bid_title: Wildlife Removal Services 2024
bid_description: The scope of work for this RFP is the mitigation of nuisance animals. The Vermont Agency of Transportation is seeking licensed trappers to remove problem animals from our roadways and structures to preserve the integrity of our infrastructure. The State would like bids for removal, elimination, or relocation of these problem animals. This work will be done within the States right of way on interstates and secondary routes as well as State owned property such as rest areas and garage facilities.

bid_title: Construction Claims Legal Services 2024
bid_description: The Vermont Agency of Transportation (VTrans), Standard Specifications for Construction contains a Contractor Claim resolution process. It is the intent of the Agency to enter into retainer contracts with up to 5 law firms (Firm) to assist VTrans in bringing Contractor Claims to resolution. The Firm will be assigned a specific claim or project by the VTrans Construction Engineer. It is the intent, that the Firm will provide legal support until the claim has been fully resolved. All work will be performed in consultation with the Assistant Attorney General for VTrans.

bid_title: General Environmental Services 2024
bid_description: Federal and state laws require that the Vermont Agency of Transportation (VTrans) must consider the impacts and potential consequences of transportation projects on the environment and obtain applicable environmental resource regulatory clearances and/ or permits prior to project construction. The Environmental Section of the VTrans Project Delivery Bureau is the unit responsible for coordinating with federal and state resource regulatory agencies during project development to obtain clearances and permits. This is generally accomplished directly by agency staff or by agency staff using the services of contracted consultants. Given that VTrans works on roadways, bridges, bike/ pedestrian trails, railroads, and airports; the Contractor and/ or his/ her subcontractor may be required to assess a wide variety of resources under numerous scenarios involving various transportation modal projects. To accomplish these objectives the Project Delivery Bureau Environmental Section requires the services of consulting firms employing environmental and cultural resource scientists, technicians, specialists, and sub-consultants.

bid_title: Asset Management Consultant Services 2024
bid_description: The Vermont Agency of Transportation (VTrans) is committed to utilizing asset management principles to manage its transportation infrastructure. This commitment may require Consultant services to facilitate the completion of several ongoing and planned initiatives in the areas of asset, risk, and performance management. VTrans seeks to retain qualified Consultants who have experience working on transportation planning and engineering projects. Consultants are expected to be capable of providing a suite of services encompassing asset management, risk management, and performance management. Consultant services are expected to be delivered on an on-call basis to complement and support VTrans’ efforts. Consultants are not required to have expertise in all areas, but all Consultants shall have expertise in at least one of the three major management disciplines noted above. Consultants are requested to provide a short list of Subconsultants with whom they have an agreement to work with under this retainer contract. Consultants shall provide documentation of the Subconsultant’s expertise and note whether they have prior experience working with the Subconsultant. Consultants may be required to work with the Subconsultants that they specify in their proposal, particularly if VTrans wishes to utilize that Subconsultant’s skill set.

bid_title: ADA Compliant Passenger Elevator - Architectural & Engineering Services
bid_description: BDCC seeks proposals from certified engineers and architects for the design and cost estimation of an ADA-compliant passenger elevator at our Cotton Mill facility. The building is a three-story, 120,000 SF former mill (330' x 121', 50' tall) repurposed into commercial units. The elevator must be strategically located for convenient access to common areas and the exterior. The scope includes site selection, machine type, machine room, hoist way design, engineering drawings, and cost estimates for A/E services and construction.

bid_title: Comprehensive Economic Development Strategy
bid_description: Assistance in the development of a Comprehensive Economic Development Strategy (CEDS) for the Southern Vermont Economic Development Zone.

bid_title: Manufactured Housing Units - turnkey purchase and installation
bid_description: Brattleboro Development Credit Corporation Real Estate Holdings II, Inc. is seeking proposals to procure and install nineteen manufactured housing units at the Mountain Home Park mobile home community in Brattleboro Vermont. The project seeks single-wide homes of several sizes and layouts that meet Zero Energy Ready Homes specifications (and others). Pleas see the attached RFP document.

bid_title: Demolition of Buildings at 50 South Main Street
bid_description: INVITATION TO BID DEPARTMENT OF BUILDINGS AND GENERAL SERVICES STATE OF VERMONT Contractors are invited to bid on the Demolition of Buildings at 50 South Main Street for Buildings and General Services on behalf of the Agency of Transportation in Barre City, Vermont. This project consists of, but is not limited to: The contractor shall demolish two (2) buildings in Barre City located on Vermont Route 14 (South Main Street) including the dwelling at 50 South Main Street and the detached garage. All components of the buildings shall be removed or decommissioned including foundations and utilities. The contractor shall remove both structures from the property including the foundations (with the exception of the poured concrete section of the garage foundation); driveway pavement; and all service lines (e.g., electrical, cable, telephone, water) to the residence up to the curb stop. The contractor shall grade and level with clean material to promote positive drainage away from the existing railroad track structure. The contractor shall complete the intended work in a manner that does not negatively impact the adjacent parcel or dwelling. The contractor will be held responsible for all damages to the adjacent parcel or dwelling if any occur while executing the intended work at 50 South Main Street. All damages shall be repaired or replaced by the contractor without cost to the State of Vermont and to the satisfaction of the Engineer. The contractor shall note that concrete block wall comprised of large solid concrete blocks is located behind the dwelling. It is considered independent of the structure and any removal of the dwelling and garage should have no effect on the slope behind them. However, the contractor shall note no excavation in front of the concrete block wall is allowed that could destabilize the wall as well as the global stability of the larger slope behind the dwelling and garage. The contractor shall completely remove the garage structure and its walls other than the poured concrete section. The contractor shall remove and reset the existing large concrete blocks that are adjacent to the railroad tracks in a stepped U-shape manner at the approximate foundation location of the garage to retain the soil in this area. Any remaining concrete blocks shall be used as fill within the existing garage footprint as well as additional clean, suitable material provided by the contractor. Hazardous material investigations have been completed and the findings included in the contract documents. Asbestos containing material requiring abatement have been identified and removed under a separate project. Numerous lead-bearing building components were identified and can be found in the following document: TCLP Lead Sampling report for the residential structure and garage at 50 South Main Street dated January 20, 2023. Prior to the start of construction, the contractor is required to submit a Traffic Control Plan to VTrans for review and approval to ensure traveling vehicles along Vermont Route 14 (South Main Street) do not stop within the existing at-grade crossing limits during construction. The contractor shall provide advance warning to traveling vehicles utilizing advanced warning signs, barrels and/or cones, highway flaggers, and other traffic control features. Revision Date: July 20, 2023 Page | 2 During construction the contractor is advised that all construction shall be completed in accordance with the Special Conditions for the Removal/Demolition of a Structure provided by the City of Barre Office of Planning & Permitting. Sealed Bids accompanied by proper Bid Security will be received by the Department of Buildings and General Services, at 133 State Street, Montpelier, Vermont 05633-8000, until April 12, 2024 at 4:30 PM. Documents may be obtained from Blueprints Etc, 20 Farrell Street, South Burlington VT 05403, by phone at 802-865-4503, by fax at 802-865-0027 or email to: orders@blueprintsetc.com. Project Manuals and Plans are available for preview at: http://www.blueprintsetc.com in the Public Plan Room. Any and all notifications, releases and addendums associated with this project will be posted at http://www.blueprintsetc.com. There is a non-refundable fee for each set of documents purchased. Fee to Include one (1) Hard Copy & one (1) Digital CD-ROM Copy: $TBD 1. Please be advised that all notifications, releases, and addendums associated with this RFP will be posted on-line in the plan room where the original solicitation resides unless otherwise determined that a hard copy is necessary. The state will make no attempt to contact contractors with updated information. It is the responsibility of each contractor to periodically check the posting site for any and all notifications, releases and addendums associated with the RFP. 2. NOTE: On occasion hard copy addendums may be required due to size or type of media/requirements. If applicable and as determined by the Department of Buildings and General Services, addendums that require hard copy distribution, a copy of such addenda will be mailed or delivered for each set of plans and specifications issued to the bidders, prior to the bid date. However, it is the responsibility of the bidder to be sure they have received all addenda, and must so state the number of addenda they have received on the proposal. 3. If Bidders choose to pull information from other third-party sites, Bidders’ do so at their own risk as there is one official source of information for documents as indicated above. QUESTION AND ANSWER PERIOD: Any vendor requiring clarification of any section of this RFP or wishing to comment or take exception to any requirements of the RFP must submit specific questions in writing to BGS.OPCVendorDocs@vermont.gov no later than 4:30 PM on April 1, 2024. All questions should include Demolition of Buildings at 50 South Main Street Project in the subject line. Any comments, questions, or exceptions not raised in writing on or before the last day of the question period are waived. At the close of the question period a copy of all questions or comments and the State's responses will be posted at http://www.blueprintsetc.com. Every effort will be made to post this information as soon as possible after the question period ends, contingent on the number and complexity of the questions. Bidder’s attention is directed to: 1. General Conditions for Construction Contracts. It is the Bidder’s responsibility to thoroughly read and comply with all requirements. Please pay close attention due to changes that have been made. Revision Date: July 20, 2023 Page | 3 2. Funding Source: This project is being funded using Vermont Capital Construction Act funds and/or American Rescue Plan Act (ARPA) funds, and federal funds that require compliance with the Davis-Bacon Act. In addition to the various requirements of the Davis-Bacon Act, wages for construction employees shall be paid using no less than the higher of either the federal (Davis-Bacon Act) or Vermont’s Prevailing Wage and Fringe Benefit Rates. Please note that when procurements are supported by federal funds, SOV business users must take affirmative steps that include at least the following Socioeconomic affirmative steps per 2 C.F.R. § 200.321: 1. Placing qualified small and minority businesses and women’s business enterprises on solicitation lists; 2. Assuring that small and minority businesses and women’s business enterprises are solicited whenever they are potential sources; 3. Dividing total requirements, when economically feasible, into smaller tasks or quantities to permit maximum participation by small and minority businesses, and women’s business enterprises; 4. Establishing delivery schedules, where the requirement permits, which encourage participation by small and minority businesses, and women’s business enterprises; 5. Using the services and assistance, as appropriate, of such organizations as the Small Business Administration and the Minority Business Development Agency of the Department of Commerce; and 6. Requiring the prime/general contractor, if subcontracts are to be let, to take the same affirmative steps as listed in numbers 1 through 5. This project is being funded in whole or in part using federal monies. If a bidder requires assistance in preparing their proposal, registering with SAM.gov or needs guidance on socioeconomic certifications, the bidder may contact the Agency of Commerce & Community Development (ACCD), Department of Economic Development (DED), APEX Accelerator. The Vermont APEX Accelerator (formerly the Procurement Technical Assistance Center (PTAC)) specializes in helping small businesses navigate the documentation associated with State and Federal procurement. There is no cost to the Contractor for assistance provided by APEX Accelerator. Their website is: https://accd.vermont.gov/economic-development/programs/ptac 3. NOTICE TO BIDDERS – PROHIBITION OF RUSSIAN GOODS: The Contractor is hereby notified that, pursuant to Vermont Executive Order No. 02-22, dated March 3, 2022, the purchase of Russian-sourced goods and goods produced by Russian entities (defined as institutions or companies that are headquartered in Russia or have their principal place of business in Russia) is prohibited. The awarded Contractor must fill out and sign the Executive Order 02-22 Vendor Certification as part of the Contract awarding process. This Revision Date: July 20, 2023 Page | 4 certification is required for all subcontracts for work performed solely for the State of Vermont and subcontracts for work performed in the State of Vermont. 4. BID SUBMISSION INSTRUCTIONS: a. CLOSING DATE: Bids must be received by the State by the due date specified on the front page of this RFP. Late bids will not be considered. i. The State may, for cause, issue an addendum to change the date and/or time when bids are due. If a change is made, the State will inform all bidders by posting at the webpage indicated on the front page of this RFP. ii. There will not be a public bid opening. However, the State will record the name, city and state for any and all bids received by the due date. b. STATE SECURITY PROCEDURES: Please be advised extra time will be needed when visiting and/or delivering information to State of Vermont offices. All individuals visiting State offices must present a valid government issued photo ID when entering the facility. i. State office buildings may be locked or otherwise closed to the public. If this RFP permits hand delivery of bids, delivery instructions will be posted at the entrance to the State facility. Any delay caused by State Security Procedures will be at the bidder’s own risk. c. BID DELIVERY INSTRUCTIONS: i. ELECTRONIC: Electronic bids will be accepted. ii. E-MAIL BIDS. Emailed bids will be accepted. Bids will be accepted via email submission to BGS.VTBids@vermont.gov . Bids must consist of a single email with a single, digitally searchable PDF attachment containing all components of the bid. Multiple emails and/or multiple attachments will not be accepted. There is an attachment size limit of 40 MB. It is the Bidder’s responsibility to compress the PDF file containing its bid, if necessary, in order to meet this size limitation. iii. FAX BIDS: Faxed bids will not be accepted. iv. PAPER BIDS: Paper format bids will not be accepted. 5. Full Bonding is required for this job. 6. CONSTRUCTION CONTRACTOR EVALUATION FORM: The Department of Buildings and General Services (BGS) may require contractor evaluations on construction projects over $100,000 or at the discretion of the BGS Director. Evaluations will be used to compile contractor’s performance on BGS projects to provide a history and assessment of the contractor’s performance. 7. It is the Bidder’s responsibility to thoroughly read and comply with all instructions and requirements of this bid solicitation. bid_title: REBID Electric Vehicle Charging Systems Testing Equipment
department: Buildings & General Svs, Office of Purchasing & Contracting

bid_title: Rutland County Courthouse & Office Door Replacement Project
department: Buildings & General Svs, Office of Purchasing & Contracting
bid_description: STATE OF VERMONT Department of Buildings & General Services REQUEST FOR PROPOSALS Rutland County Courthouse & Office Door Replacement Project Rutland, Vermont January 2025 INVITATION TO BID DEPARTMENT OF BUILDINGS AND GENERAL SERVICES STATE OF VERMONT Contractors are invited to bid on the Rutland County Courthouse & Office Building Door Replacement Project for Buildings and General Services at 9 Merchants Row in Rutland, Vermont. This project consists of, but is not limited to: Replace eleven single and eight double interior courtroom doors and their hardware, reusing the existing door frames. Critical to the project is to match as closely as possible the existing veneer wood cut, grain, color, and finish. Sealed Bids accompanied by proper Bid Security shall be emailed to the Department of Buildings and General Services, at BGS.VTBids@vermont.gov, until February 12, 2025 at 4:30 PM. Documents may be obtained from Blueprints Etc, 20 Farrell Street, South Burlington VT 05403, by phone at 802- 865-4503, by fax at 802-865-0027 or email to: orders@blueprintsetc.com. Project Manuals and Plans are available for preview at: http://www.blueprintsetc.com in the Public Plan Room. Any and all notifications, releases and addendums associated with this project will be posted at http://www.blueprintsetc.com. There is a non-refundable fee for each set of documents purchased. Fee to Include one (1) Hard Copy & one (1) Digital CD-ROM Copy: $TBD 1. Please be advised that all notifications, releases, and addendums associated with this RFP will be posted on-line in the plan room where the original solicitation resides unless otherwise determined that a hard copy is necessary. The state will make no attempt to contact contractors with updated information. It is the responsibility of each contractor to periodically check the posting site for any and all notifications, releases and addendums associated with the RFP. 2. NOTE: On occasion hard copy addendums may be required due to size or type of media/requirements. If applicable and as determined by the Department of Buildings and General Services, addendums that require hard copy distribution, a copy of such addenda will be mailed or delivered for each set of plans and specifications issued to the bidders, prior to the bid date. However, it is the responsibility of the bidder to be sure they have received all addenda and must so state the number of addenda they have received on the proposal. 3. If Bidders choose to pull information from other third-party sites, Bidders’ do so at their own risk as there is one official source of information for documents as indicated above. There will be a non-mandatory pre-bid meeting at the site on January 15, 2025 at 11:00 AM. Meet outside the main entrance of the courthouse. All individuals will need to go through security metal detector. QUESTION AND ANSWER PERIOD: Any vendor requiring clarification of any section of this RFP or wishing to comment or take exception to any requirements of the RFP must submit specific questions in writing to BGS.OPCVendorDocs@vermont.gov no later than 4:30 PM on January 29, 2025. All questions should include Rutland County Courthouse & Office Building Door Replacement Project in the subject line. Any comments, questions, or exceptions not raised in writing on or before the last day of the question period are waived. At the close of the question period a copy of all questions or comments and the State's responses will be posted at http://www.blueprintsetc.com. Every effort will be made to post this information as soon as possible after the question period ends, contingent on the number and complexity of the questions. Bidder’s attention is directed to: 1. General Conditions for Construction Contracts. It is the Bidder’s responsibility to thoroughly read and comply with all requirements. Please pay close attention due to changes that have been made. 2. Funding Source: This project is being funded, in whole or in part, through the American Rescue Plan Act (ARPA) funds and/or Vermont Capital Construction Act funds. Wages for construction employees shall be paid no less than the Vermont Prevailing Wage and Fringe Benefit Rate requirements (reference Instructions to Bidders, Prevailing Wage Rate Requirements). A complete list of occupations and associated wage rates are available on the internet at: http://www.vtlmi.info/lmipub.htm 3. NOTICE TO BIDDERS – PROHIBITION OF RUSSIAN GOODS: The Contractor is hereby notified that, pursuant to Vermont Executive Order No. 02-22, dated March 3, 2022, the purchase of Russian-sourced goods and goods produced by Russian entities (defined as institutions or companies that are headquartered in Russia or have their principal place of business in Russia) is prohibited. The awarded Contractor must fill out and sign the Executive Order 02-22 Vendor Certification as part of the Contract awarding process. This certification is required for all subcontracts for work performed solely for the State of Vermont and subcontracts for work performed in the State of Vermont. 4. BID SUBMISSION INSTRUCTIONS: a. CLOSING DATE: Bids must be received by the State by the due date specified on the front page of this RFP. Late bids will not be considered. i. The State may, for cause, issue an addendum to change the date and/or time when bids are due. If a change is made, the State will inform all bidders by posting at the webpage indicated on the front page of this RFP. ii. There will not be a public bid opening. However, the State will record the name, city and state for any and all bids received by the due date. b. BID DELIVERY INSTRUCTIONS: i. ELECTRONIC: Electronic bids will be accepted. ii. E-MAIL BIDS. Emailed bids will be accepted. Bids will be accepted via email submission to BGS.VTBids@vermont.gov. Bids must consist of a single email with a single, digitally searchable PDF attachment containing all components of the bid. Multiple emails and/or multiple attachments will not be accepted. There is an attachment size limit of 40 MB. It is the Bidder’s responsibility to compress the PDF file containing its bid, if necessary, in order to meet this size limitation. iii. FAX BIDS: Faxed bids will not be accepted. iv. PAPER FORMAT: Paper format bids will not be accepted. 5. Full Bonding is required for this job. 6. SUBMITTAL EXCHANGE®: Contractor shall obtain a license for the State to utilize Submittal Exchange for the purposes of this project. The State and its representatives will have full control of the use of Submittal Exchange by authorized users of the State. Submittal Exchange®, a web-based collaboration software system, shall be used to provide an on-line database and repository, which shall be used to transmit and track project-related documents. Based on an existing contract between the State and Submittal Exchange, the State anticipates that training and support during this project will be provided by Submittal Exchange at no additional cost to the selected contractor(s). 7. CONSTRUCTION CONTRACTOR EVALUATION FORM: The Department of Buildings and General Services (BGS) may require contractor evaluations on construction projects over $100,000 or at the discretion of the BGS Director. Evaluations will be used to compile a contractor’s performance on BGS projects to provide a history and assessment of the contractor’s performance. 8. It is the Bidder’s responsibility to thoroughly read and comply with all instructions and requirements of this bid solicitation.

bid_title: BGS Youth Crisis Stabilization Renovation Project
department: Buildings & General Svs, Office of Purchasing & Contracting
bid_description: INVITATION TO BID DEPARTMENT OF BUILDINGS AND GENERAL SERVICES STATE OF VERMONT Contractors are invited to bid on the Youth Crisis Stabilization Renovation Project for Buildings and General Services on behalf of the Department of Children and Families (DCF) at 185 Old Ferry Road in Brattleboro, Vermont. This project consists of, but is not limited to: The client/tenant for the project is the State of Vermont Department for Children and Families (DCF). DCF will lease renovated space from WCSO. The goal of the renovation is to create a short-term, three bed, staff-secure, residential Board and Care facility for youth in the temporary care of DCF. The scope of the renovation is limited to the basement area with some modifications at the first-floor entry and lobby in order to create a separate egress stair. The building is currently mixed-use occupancy, with Business Use and a small wood shop classified as Special Industrial. The basement currently has vacant office areas, bathrooms, kitchen and mechanical rooms. The project will be focused on a partial renovation of the basement to create a new program area which will include three bedrooms, new ADA bathroom, renovation of an old bathroom with a washer/dryer, an office, renovated kitchen and multi-purpose/recreational room. A new exterior door leading to a new exterior stair, and a previously open stair between the basement and first floor will be enclosed with a fire-barrier to provide two separate means of egress from the program area. Sealed Bids accompanied by proper Bid Security will be received by email to the Department of Buildings and General Services at BGS.VTBids@vermont.gov, until July 3, 2024, at 4:30 PM. Documents may be obtained from Blueprints, Etc., 20 Farrell Street, South Burlington, VT 05403, by phone at 802.865.4503, by fax at 802.865.0027 or email to: orders@blueprintsetc.com. Project Manuals and Plans are available for preview at: http://www.blueprintsetc.com in the Private Plan Room. Contractors shall obtain a password to access this project from Blueprints. Any and all notifications, releases and addendums associated with this project will be posted at http://www.blueprintsetc.com. There is a non-refundable fee for each set of documents purchased. Fee to Include one (1) Hard Copy & one (1) Digital CD-ROM Copy: $TBD 1. Please be advised that all notifications, releases, and addendums associated with this RFP will be posted on-line in the plan room where the original solicitation resides unless otherwise determined that a hard copy is necessary. The state will make no attempt to contact contractors with updated information. It is the responsibility of each contractor to periodically check the posting site for any and all notifications, releases and addendums associated with the RFP. 2. NOTE: On occasion hard copy addendums may be required due to size or type of media/requirements. If applicable and as determined by the Department of Buildings and General Services, addendums that require hard copy distribution, a copy of such addenda will be mailed or delivered for each set of plans and specifications issued to the bidders, prior to the bid date. However, it is the responsibility of the bidder to be sure they have received all addenda and must so state the number of addenda they have received on the proposal. 3. If Bidders choose to pull information from other third-party sites, Bidders do so at their own risk as there is one official source of information for documents as indicated above. There will be a non-mandatory second pre-bid meeting at the site on June 7, 2024at 9:00 AM. Bidders to meet at front entrance. QUESTION AND ANSWER PERIOD: Any vendor requiring clarification of any section of this RFP or wishing to comment or take exception to any requirements of the RFP must submit specific questions in writing to BGS.OPCVendorDocs@vermont.gov no later than 4:30 PM on June 7, 2024. All questions should include Youth Crisis Stabilization Renovation Project in the subject line. Any comments, questions, or exceptions not raised in writing on or before the last day of the question period are waived. At the close of the question period a copy of all questions or comments and the State's responses will be posted at http://www.blueprintsetc.com. Every effort will be made to post this information as soon as possible after the question period ends, contingent on the number and complexity of the questions. Bidder’s attention is directed to: 1. General Conditions for Construction Contracts. It is the Bidder’s responsibility to thoroughly read and comply with all requirements. Please pay close attention due to the changes that have been made. 2. Funding Source: This project is being funded, in whole or in part, through Department of Children and Families (DCF) funds. Wages for construction employees shall be paid no less than the Vermont Prevailing Wage and Fringe Benefit Rate requirements (reference Instructions to Bidders, Prevailing Wage Rate Requirements). A complete list of occupations and associated wage rates are available on the internet at: http://www.vtlmi.info/lmipub.htm If a bidder requires assistance in preparing their proposal, registering with SAM.gov or needs guidance on socioeconomic certifications, the bidder may contact the Agency of Commerce & Community Development (ACCD), Department of Economic Development (DED), APEX Accelerator. The Vermont APEX Accelerator (formerly the Procurement Technical Assistance Center (PTAC)) specializes in helping small businesses navigate the documentation associated with State and Federal procurement. There is no cost to the Contractor for assistance provided by APEX Accelerator. Their website is: https://accd.vermont.gov/economicdevelopment/ programs/ptac 3. NOTICE TO BIDDERS – PROHIBITION OF RUSSIAN GOODS: The Contractor is hereby notified that, pursuant to Vermont Executive Order No. 02-22, dated March 3, 2022, the purchase of Russian-sourced goods and goods produced by Russian entities (defined as institutions or companies that are headquartered in Russia or have their principal place of business in Russia) is prohibited. The awarded Contractor must fill out and sign the Executive Order 02-22 Vendor Certification as part of the Contract awarding process. This certification is required for all subcontracts for work performed solely for the State of Vermont and subcontracts for work performed in the State of Vermont. 4. BIDDER QUALIFICATION PROCESS DOCUMENT: The Department of Buildings and General Services is requiring that all contractors meet certain minimum qualifications to be eligible to bid on this project. 5. BID SUBMISSION INSTRUCTIONS: a. CLOSING DATE: Bids must be received by the State by the due date specified on the front page of this RFP. Late bids will not be considered. i. The State may, for cause, issue an addendum to change the date and/or time when bids are due. If a change is made, the State will inform all bidders by posting it on the webpage indicated on the front page of this RFP. ii. There will not be a public bid opening. However, the State will record the name, city and state for any and all bids received by the due date. b. BID DELIVERY INSTRUCTIONS: i. ELECTRONIC: Electronic bids will be accepted. ii. E-MAIL BIDS. Emailed bids will be accepted. Bids will be accepted via email submission to BGS.VTBids@vermont.gov. Bids must consist of a single email with a single, digitally searchable PDF attachment containing all components of the bid. Multiple emails and/or multiple attachments will not be accepted. There is an attachment size limit of 40 MB. It is the Bidder’s responsibility to compress the PDF file containing its bid, if necessary, in order to meet this size limitation. iii. FAX BIDS: Faxed bids will not be accepted. iv. PAPER FORMAT: Paper format bids will not be accepted. 6. Full Bonding is required for this job. 7. CONSTRUCTION CONTRACTOR EVALUATION FORM: The Department of Buildings and General Services (BGS) may require contractor evaluations on construction projects over $100,000 or at the discretion of the BGS Director. Evaluations will be used to compile contractor’s performance on BGS projects to provide a history and assessment of the contractor’s performance. 8. It is the Bidder’s responsibility to thoroughly read and comply with all instructions and requirements of this bid solicitation.

bid_title: KINGSLAND STATE PARK UTILITY, STORMWATER AND ROAD IMPROVEMENTS PROJECT
department: Buildings & General Svs, Office of Purchasing & Contracting
bid_description: Contractors are invited to bid on the Kingsland Bay - Utility, Stormwater & Road Improvements Project for the Buildings and General Services on behalf of the Agency of Natural Resources – Forests, Parks and Recreation at 787 Kingsland Bay State Park in Ferrisburgh, Vermont. This project consists of, but is not limited to: Kingsland Bay State Park currently has an entrance road that splits at a point and becomes two one-way entrance/exit lanes. The exit lane is directly next to the shore on a steep embankment and is prone to erosion. This project will eliminate the one-way exit lane that is running next to the shore and widen the entrance lane to accommodate two-way traffic. This widened lane provides greater separation between the shoreline and the road. The contact station will be relocated/rebuilt to align with the widened/relocated road. Existing overhead utilities (and their associated vegetation maintenance and access) will be removed and relocated underground in better suited locations. The larger project aims to decrease the overall impervious surfaces on the parcel as well as provide treatment to stormwater runoff and provide increased water quality draining to the lake. The new impervious surfaces proposed as part of the widening along with some existing impervious surfaces are to be treated via two gravel wetlands for Stormwater runoff prior to draining back to Lake Champlain. Sealed Bids accompanied by proper Bid Security shall be received by email to BGS.VTBids@vermont.gov, until September 11, 2024 at 4:30 PM. Documents may be obtained from Blueprints Etc, 20 Farrell Street, South Burlington VT 05403, by phone at 802-865-4503, by fax at 802-865-0027 or email to: orders@blueprintsetc.com. Project Manuals and Plans are available for preview at: http://www.blueprintsetc.com in the Public Plan Room. Any and all notifications, releases and addendums associated with this project will be posted at http://www.blueprintsetc.com. There is a non-refundable fee for each set of documents purchased. Fee to Include one (1) Hard Copy & one (1) Digital CD-ROM Copy: $TBD 1. Please be advised that all notifications, releases, and addendums associated with this RFP will be posted on-line in the plan room where the original solicitation resides unless otherwise determined that a hard copy is necessary. The state will make no attempt to contact contractors with updated information. It is the responsibility of each contractor to periodically check the posting site for any and all notifications, releases and addendums associated with the RFP. 2. NOTE: On occasion hard copy addendums may be required due to size or type of media/requirements. If applicable and as determined by the Department of Buildings and General Services, addendums that require hard copy distribution, a copy of such addenda will be mailed or delivered for each set of plans and specifications issued to the bidders, prior to the bid date. However, it is the responsibility of the bidder to be sure they have received all addenda and must so state the number of addenda they have received on the proposal. 3. If Bidders choose to pull information from other third-party sites, Bidders do so at their own risk, as there is one official source of information for documents as indicated above. There will be a non-mandatory pre-bid meeting at the site on August 15, 2024 at 10:00 AM. Contractors to meet at the main entrance of Kingsland Bay State Park. QUESTION AND ANSWER PERIOD: Any vendor requiring clarification of any section of this RFP or wishing to comment or take exception to any requirements of the RFP must submit specific questions in writing to BGS.OPCVendorDocs@vermont.gov no later than 4:30 PM on August 26, 2024. All questions should include Kingsland Bay - Utility, Stormwater & Road Improvements Project in the subject line. Any comments, questions, or exceptions not raised in writing on or before the last day of the question period are waived. At the close of the question period a copy of all questions or comments and the State's responses will be posted at http://www.blueprintsetc.com. Every effort will be made to post this information as soon as possible after the question period ends, contingent on the number and complexity of the questions. Bidder’s attention is directed to: 1. General Conditions for Construction Contracts. It is the Bidder’s responsibility to thoroughly read and comply with all requirements. Please pay close attention due to changes that have been made. 2. Funding Source: This project is being funded, in whole or in part, through the American Rescue Plan Act (ARPA) funds and/or Vermont Capital Construction Act funds. Socioeconomic affirmative steps per 2 C.F.R. § 200.321: Placing qualified small and minority businesses and women’s business enterprises on solicitation lists; 1. Assuring that small and minority businesses and women’s business enterprises are solicited whenever they are potential sources; 2. Dividing total requirements, when economically feasible, into smaller tasks or quantities to permit maximum participation by small and minority businesses, and women’s business enterprises; 3. Establishing delivery schedules, where the requirement permits, which encourage participation by small and minority businesses, and women’s business enterprises; 4. Using the services and assistance, as appropriate, of such organizations as the Small Business Administration and the Minority Business Development Agency of the Department of Commerce; and 5. Requiring the prime/general contractor, if subcontracts are to be let, to take the same affirmative steps as listed in numbers 1 through 5. 3. BYRD ANTI-LOBBYING CERTIFICATION Contractor has provided the certification required by the Byrd Anti-Lobbying Amendment, 31 U.S.C. § 1352 (as amended, and will follow the requirements for certification of each lower tier (subcontract) to disclose any lobbying with non-federal funds that takes place in connection with obtaining any federal award. Such disclosures will be forwarded from tier to tier up to the Contractor who in turn will forward the certification(s) to the federal awarding agency. 4. DOMESTIC PREFERENCE FOR PROCUREMENTS As appropriate, and to the extent consistent with law, the contractor should, to the greatest extent practicable, provide a preference for the purchase, acquisition, or use of goods, products, or materials produced in the United States. This includes, but is not limited to iron, aluminum, steel, cement, and other manufactured products. For purposes of this clause: Produced in the United States means, for iron and steel products, that all manufacturing processes, from the initial melting stage through the application of coatings, occurred in the United States. Manufactured products mean items and construction materials composed in whole or in part of non-ferrous metals such as aluminum; plastics and polymer-based products such as polyvinyl chloride pipe; aggregates such as concrete; glass, including optical fiber; and lumber.” 5. NOTICE TO BIDDERS – PROHIBITION OF RUSSIAN GOODS: The Contractor is hereby notified that, pursuant to Vermont Executive Order No. 02-22, dated March 3, 2022, the purchase of Russian-sourced goods and goods produced by Russian entities (defined as institutions or companies that are headquartered in Russia or have their principal place of business in Russia) is prohibited. The awarded Contractor must fill out and sign the Executive Order 02-22 Vendor Certification as part of the Contract awarding process. This certification is required for all subcontracts for work performed solely for the State of Vermont and subcontracts for work performed in the State of Vermont. 6. BIDDER QUALIFICATION PROCESS DOCUMENT: The Department of Buildings and General Services is requiring that all contractors meet certain minimum qualifications to be eligible to bid on this project. 7. BID SUBMISSION INSTRUCTIONS: a. CLOSING DATE: Bids must be received by the State by the due date specified on the front page of this RFP. Late bids will not be considered. i. The State may, for cause, issue an addendum to change the date and/or time when bids are due. If a change is made, the State will inform all bidders by posting it on the webpage indicated on the front page of this RFP. ii. There will not be a public bid opening. However, the State will record the name, city and state for any and all bids received by the due date. b. BID DELIVERY INSTRUCTIONS: i. ELECTRONIC: Electronic bids will be accepted. ii. E-MAIL BIDS. Emailed bids will be accepted. Bids will be accepted via email submission to BGS.VTBids@vermont.gov . Bids must consist of a single email with a single, digitally searchable PDF attachment containing all components of the bid. Multiple emails and/or multiple attachments will not be accepted. There is an attachment size limit of 40 MB. It is the Bidder’s responsibility to compress the PDF file containing its bid, if necessary, in order to meet this size limitation. It is also the Bidder's responsibility to ensure that their own email system can send and receive messages up to this size. iii. FAX BIDS: Faxed bids will not be accepted. iv. PAPER BIDS: Paper format bids will not be accepted. 8. Full Bonding is required for this job. 9. CONSTRUCTION CONTRACTOR EVALUATION FORM: The Department of Buildings and General Services (BGS) may require contractor evaluations on construction projects over $100,000 or at the discretion of the BGS Director. Evaluations will be used to compile the contractor’s performance on BGS projects to provide a history and assessment of the contractor’s performance. 10. It is the Bidder’s responsibility to thoroughly read and comply with all instructions and requirements of this bid solicitation.
